Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility did not complete variable interval checks every 15
minutes or less for multiple days.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
The Complainant is this Consultant as this Consultant was
made aware of the information during a quarterly
unannounced visit to the facility on 8/17/23.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/30/23. Supervisor reported Staff 1 is a typical third shift staff
member who works Sunday-Wednesday and Staff 2 is a typical
third shift staff member who works Thursday-Saturday. Supervisor
reported Staff 2 had been on vacation for two weeks, but she was
able to speak to Staff 1 about the allegations. Staff 1 told
Supervisor she sits in the hallway to avoid the youth going AWOL
but does not do eyes-on checks by going into each room because
the youth do not like it when staff open their doors as the light
shines in their faces. Supervisor reported Staff 1 was not
completing observation logs during her shift because Staff 1 said
she could not find the blank log sheets. Supervisor reported she is
not aware how long it’s been since Staff 1 stopped documenting
observations, but Staff 1 has been completing observation log
sheets since 8/19/23 when Supervisor provided her with them.
Supervisor reported she was unaware these checks were an issue
until the unannounced visit completed by this Consultant on
8/17/23. Supervisor reported she spoke with Staff 1 on 8/19/23
and explained the process for conducting checks, importance of
completing checks and what her requirements were. Supervisor
reported staff are not conducting or completing eyes-on checks on
2

the youth after 8 am, even if the youth are sleeping or are in their
rooms for extended periods of time.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 9/18/23.
Staff 1 reported prior to this investigation, her understanding of her
responsibilities were to ensure the youth do not go AWOL
overnight and check on the youth if she heard something unusual.
She reported the youth are in their rooms but are frequently not
sleeping until after 2:30 AM. She reported after 3:00 AM, she is
very tired and tends to rest her eyes at times, but reported she
does not sleep. Staff 1 reported she wants to reduce her hours
because it’s very hard for her to stay awake and it’s too much for
her to go up and down the stairs so often due to her age. Staff 1
reported having two people work during third shift would be much
better; especially if one staff member was downstairs and one
staff member was upstairs.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/21/23. Staff 2 reported
prior to this investigation, her understanding of her responsibilities
was if nothing is going on with the youth, and they are in their
rooms, she didn’t have to check on them. Staff 2 reported she was
doing checks by being around the bedrooms but did not complete
eyes-on checks. She reported she documented completing
checks every fifteen minutes or less because she checked that the
girls remained in their rooms. Staff 2 reported it would be much
easier to have two staff working third shift; especially if one staff
member was downstairs and one staff member was upstairs.
VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED:
Video footage was reviewed for three overnight shifts, which are
detailed below. It should be noted, Staff 1 was notified about the
investigation as well as reminded of her responsibilities and
requirements by Supervisor on 8/19/23. It should also be noted,
Staff 3 normally works second shift, but was helping out on third
shift from 8/23/23-8/24/23 due to Staff 2 being on vacation.
• 8/8/23 at 11:30 PM through 8/9/23 at 7:00 AM
o Basement: Staff 1 did not go downstairs the entirety
of the shift, and therefore, did not complete any
eyes-on interval checks as required.
o Upstairs: Staff 1 did not complete any eyes-on

of the shift, Staff 1 was sitting in the chair at the end
of the upstairs bedroom hallway under a blanket and
it looks as if she is sleeping. However, there were a
few times she was on her phone or moving her foot.

o Upstairs: Staff 1 completed eyes-on checks at 12:37

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Bethany Christian Services Bellaview Policies and
Procedures: Staff to Resident Ratio (updated 8/3/23) states
when residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval,
eye-on checks of the residents, which should not exceed
15 minutes. It should be noted, this information is repeated
under the information “during awake hours” as well as
“during overnight hours”. It notes staff must be always
awake. It also notes visual checks must be electronically
record on the unit computer, and if it’s not possible,
monitoring must be done via paper documentation.
• Bed Check Observation Log for 8/23/23-8/24/23 completed
by Staff 3 outlines interval checks Staff 3 reports she
completed. It should be noted five of the interval checks
listed exceed fifteen minutes. In addition, these checks are
inconsistent with the review of video footage outlined
above.
• Bed Check Observation Log for 8/26/23-8/27/23 completed
by Staff 1 outlines interval checks Staff 3 reports she
completed. It should be noted these checks are

inconsistent with the review of video footage outlined
above.
• Bed Check Observation Logs for overnight shifts on
8/11/23-8/12/23, 8/12/23-8/13/23 and 8/13/23-8/14/23
completed by Staff 2 were reviewed. It should be noted
checks were written as being completed every fifteen
minutes exactly, rather than at variable intervals.
• Bed Check Observation Logs for overnight shifts on
8/21/23-8/22/23, 8/22/23-8/23/23, 8/27/23-8/28/23, 8/28/23-
8/29/23, 8/29/23-8/30/23 completed by Staff 1 outlines
interval checks Staff 1 reported she completed. It should be
noted there were multiple interval checks listed exceeding
fifteen minutes.
• Staff 1 completed Shadow Shifts and Apprentice Shift to
learn the responsibilities of her role and policies associated
with her role (including observation checks & the facility’s
staff to resident ratio policy) between November-December
2018. Staff 1 signed off that she understood third shift
duties (including interval checks) on 8/17/23. Staff 1 has
one disciplinary record in her employee file (a performance
coaching form), which is related to this investigation.
• Staff 2 completed Orientation, Shadow Shifts, and an
Apprentice Shift to learn the responsibilities of her role and
policies associated with her role (including observation
checks & the facility’s staff to resident ratio policy) between
December 2022-January 2023. Staff 2 does not have any
disciplinary records in her employee file.
• Staff 3 completed Orientation, Shadow Shifts, and an
Apprentice Shift to learn the responsibilities of her role and
policies associated with her role (including observation
checks & the facility’s staff to resident ratio policy) between
January-February 2023. Staff 2 does not have any
disciplinary records in her employee file.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted, documents reviewed, and video
footage reviewed, this violation is established. Staff 1, Staff 2 and
Staff 3 failed to conduct eyes-on checks in intervals not to exceed
fifteen minutes while youth were in their rooms and/or sleeping. In
addition, Supervisor reported eyes-on interval checks are not
being completed or documented past third shift, even if youth are
in their rooms and/or sleeping.
5

Technical Assistance:
o Interval checks must be conducted not to exceed 15
minutes; however, they should not be every 15 minutes
exactly. Youth pay attention to when staff check on them,
so if staff are checking every 15 minutes exactly, youth will
notice and will take advantage of it.
o Interval checks must be conducted when residents are
outside of the direct supervision of staff. Therefore, if youth
are in their rooms, outside, etc. interval checks must be
conducted by staff anytime the youth is not within their line
of sight (not to exceed 15 minutes). Staff will have to
monitor and time how long youth are out of their sight to
ensure they meet this requirement.
o Interval checks must be conducted eyes on, which means
staff must visually see the youth and verify they are okay.
Consultation:
• Ensure all staff policies and forms are written in a staff
member’s primary language to ensure ease of
understanding. Consultant provided “How To” instructions
to facility on 9/29/23 to convert forms.
Conclusion Violation Established

Conclusion Violation Established
